page.text: P20 profile:
Agenda 2030 includes the specific commitment to Leave
No One Behind. Together with Sustainable Development
Goal 10 to reduce inequality, this requires faster than average
progress for the poorest. The test is whether the gap between
the poorest 20% of people (the P20) and everyone else
is reducing or getting wider.
The P20 Initiative uses data to show whether the poorest 20%
of people are getting their fair share of attention, investment
and opportunity. It uses three bellwether indicators of progress:
income, nutrition and civil registration and it promotes all data
being disaggregated by Income Quintile, Gender, Geography,
Age and Disability.
This profile provides key available data about the status
of the P20 in Algeria.
420,145 people in Algeria are among
the poorest 20% of the world’s population – the
global P20. That is 1% of the total population
and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Algeria – live on less than $5.07
a day compared with an average $9.73
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 1999 the gap between the national P20 and
everyone else in Algeria was $4.54 and
in 2013 it was $5.71.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
Nutrition is fundamental to the ability to learn
and earn. Children who experience poor nutrition
can suffer lifelong disadvantage as a result.
In Algeria, 12% of children under
five years old experience stunting. In the national P20 13%
experience stunting compared with 11%
of the rest of the population.

text.b: stunting in children in the P20 compared with rest of country

page.text: Source: Development Initiatives based on UNICEF-WHO joint child
malnutrition estimates
Civil Registration means people count and
have rights. Worldwide around 71% of children
are birth registered. If you are born into the
poorest 20% of people you are much less likely
to have your birth registered.
In Algeria 99% of births in the
national P20 are registered compared to
100% in the rest of the population.

text.b: birth registration rates for children under five

page.text: Birth registration rates in Algeria
have stayed constant.
Source: Development Initiatives based on World Bank World Development Indicators:
Completeness of birth registration %
Education is fundamental to a person’s
life chances.
As of 2008, 47% of people in Algeria have
completed secondary school education.

text.b: percentage who have completed secondary education

page.text: 38% of people in the national P20 have completed
a secondary education compared with 62%
of the rest of the population.
Source: Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Poor health plays a major part in keeping people
in poverty. If you are among the P20 you are more
likely to suffer from preventable diseases and
to die earlier.
In Algeria the under-five mortality rate
is 25 per 1,000 live births.
Data is not available that allows us to disaggregate
under-five mortality based on income and
therefore we are unable to see this information
for the P20 versus the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Year of latest available data: 2013 (2011 $PPP)
Based on latest available data which varies between countries – see original source
Based on latest available data which varies between countries – see original source

page.text: 71% of people in the national P20 have completed
a secondary education compared with 84%
of the rest of the population.

Poor health plays a major part in keeping people

likely to suffer from preventable diseases and

Source: Development Initiatives based on Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Year of latest available data: 2013 (2011 $PPP)

P20 profile:
Agenda 2030 includes the specific commitment to Leave
No One Behind. Together with Sustainable Development
Goal 10 to reduce inequality, this requires faster than average
progress for the poorest. The test is whether the gap between
the poorest 20% of people (the P20) and everyone else
is reducing or getting wider.
The P20 Initiative uses data to show whether the poorest 20%
of people are getting their fair share of attention, investment
and opportunity. It uses three bellwether indicators of progress:
income, nutrition and civil registration and it promotes all data
being disaggregated by Income Quintile, Gender, Geography,
Age and Disability.
This profile provides key available data about the status
of the P20 in Sudan.
6,311,779 people in Sudan are among
the poorest 20% of the world’s population – the
global P20. That is 17% of the total population
and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Sudan – live on between $1.59
and $2.71 a day compared with an average $6.66
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 1999 the gap between the national P20 and
everyone else in Sudan was $2.49 and
in 2013 it was $4.71.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
Nutrition is fundamental to the ability to learn
and earn. Children who experience poor nutrition
can suffer lifelong disadvantage as a result.
In Sudan, 38% of children under
five years old experience stunting. In the national P20 44%
experience stunting compared with 37%
of the rest of the population.

text.b: stunting in children in the P20 compared with rest of country

page.text: Source: Development Initiatives based on UNICEF-WHO joint child
malnutrition estimates

have rights. Worldwide around 71% of children

to have your birth registered.

national P20 are registered compared to
78% in the rest of the population.

P20 profile:
Agenda 2030 includes the specific commitment to Leave
No One Behind. Together with Sustainable Development
Goal 10 to reduce inequality, this requires faster than average
progress for the poorest. The test is whether the gap between
the poorest 20% of people (the P20) and everyone else
is reducing or getting wider.
The P20 Initiative uses data to show whether the poorest 20%
of people are getting their fair share of attention, investment
and opportunity. It uses three bellwether indicators of progress:
income, nutrition and civil registration and it promotes all data
being disaggregated by Income Quintile, Gender, Geography,
Age and Disability.
This profile provides key available data about the status
of the P20 in Congo.
2,349,991 people in Congo are among
the poorest 20% of the world’s population – the
global P20. That is 49% of the total population
and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Congo – live on between $0.64
and $1.23 a day compared with an average $4.71
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 1999 the gap between the national P20 and
everyone else in Congo was $2.45 and
in 2013 it was $3.89.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
Nutrition is fundamental to the ability to learn
and earn. Children who experience poor nutrition
can suffer lifelong disadvantage as a result.
In Congo, 21% of children under
five years old experience stunting. It is not possible to
disaggregate stunting rates between the
national P20 and the rest of the population.

P20 profile:
Agenda 2030 includes the specific commitment to Leave
No One Behind. Together with Sustainable Development
Goal 10 to reduce inequality, this requires faster than average
progress for the poorest. The test is whether the gap between
the poorest 20% of people (the P20) and everyone else
is reducing or getting wider.
The P20 Initiative uses data to show whether the poorest 20%
of people are getting their fair share of attention, investment
and opportunity. It uses three bellwether indicators of progress:
income, nutrition and civil registration and it promotes all data
being disaggregated by Income Quintile, Gender, Geography,
Age and Disability.
This profile provides key available data about the status
of the P20 in Swaziland.
651,972 people in Swaziland are among
the poorest 20% of the world’s population – the
global P20. That is 51% of the total population
and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Swaziland – live on between $0.64
and $1.23 a day compared with an average $5.06
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 1999 the gap between the national P20 and
everyone else in Swaziland was $3.59 and
in 2013 it was $4.21.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
Nutrition is fundamental to the ability to learn
and earn. Children who experience poor nutrition
can suffer lifelong disadvantage as a result.
In Swaziland, 26% of children under
five years old experience stunting. In the national P20 30%
experience stunting compared with 24%
of the rest of the population.

text.b: stunting in children in the P20 compared with rest of country

page.text: Source: Development Initiatives based on UNICEF-WHO joint child
malnutrition estimates
Civil Registration means people count and
have rights. Worldwide around 71% of children
are birth registered. If you are born into the
poorest 20% of people you are much less likely
to have your birth registered.
In Swaziland 39% of births in the
national P20 are registered compared to
60% in the rest of the population.

text.b: birth registration rates for children under five

page.text: Birth registration rates in Swaziland
have increased.
Source: Development Initiatives based on World Bank World Development Indicators:
Completeness of birth registration %
Education is fundamental to a person’s
life chances.

text.b: percentage who have completed secondary education

page.text: 25% of people in the national P20 have completed
a secondary education compared with 57%
of the rest of the population.
Source: Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Poor health plays a major part in keeping people
in poverty. If you are among the P20 you are more
likely to suffer from preventable diseases and
to die earlier.
In Swaziland the under-five mortality rate
is 70 per 1,000 live births.
The under-five mortality rate among the P20
is 117 per 1,000 live births compared with 102
per 1,000 live births for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Year of latest available data: 2013 (2011 $PPP)
Based on latest available data which varies between countries – see original source
Based on latest available data which varies between countries – see original source

P20 profile:
Agenda 2030 includes the specific commitment to Leave
No One Behind. Together with Sustainable Development
Goal 10 to reduce inequality, this requires faster than average
progress for the poorest. The test is whether the gap between
the poorest 20% of people (the P20) and everyone else
is reducing or getting wider.
The P20 Initiative uses data to show whether the poorest 20%
of people are getting their fair share of attention, investment
and opportunity. It uses three bellwether indicators of progress:
income, nutrition and civil registration and it promotes all data
being disaggregated by Income Quintile, Gender, Geography,
Age and Disability.
This profile provides key available data about the status
of the P20 in Liberia.
2,594,489 people in Liberia are among
the poorest 20% of the world’s population – the
global P20. That is 60% of the total population
and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Liberia – live on between $0.91
and $1.35 a day compared with an average $3.10
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 1999 the gap between the national P20 and
everyone else in Liberia was $1.58 and
in 2013 it was $2.09.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
Nutrition is fundamental to the ability to learn
and earn. Children who experience poor nutrition
can suffer lifelong disadvantage as a result.
In Liberia, 32% of children under
five years old experience stunting. In the national P20 36%
experience stunting compared with 31%
of the rest of the population.

text.b: stunting in children in the P20 compared with rest of country

page.text: Source: Development Initiatives based on UNICEF-WHO joint child
malnutrition estimates
Civil Registration means people count and
have rights. Worldwide around 71% of children
are birth registered. If you are born into the
poorest 20% of people you are much less likely
to have your birth registered.
In Liberia 16% of births in the
national P20 are registered compared to
28% in the rest of the population.

text.b: birth registration rates for children under five

page.text: Birth registration rates in Liberia
have increased.
Source: Development Initiatives based on World Bank World Development Indicators:
Completeness of birth registration %
Education is fundamental to a person’s
life chances.

text.b: percentage who have completed secondary education

page.text: 3% of people in the national P20 have completed
a secondary education compared with 26%
of the rest of the population.
Source: Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Poor health plays a major part in keeping people
in poverty. If you are among the P20 you are more
likely to suffer from preventable diseases and
to die earlier.
In Liberia the under-five mortality rate
is 67 per 1,000 live births.
The under-five mortality rate among the P20
is 130 per 1,000 live births compared with 107
per 1,000 live births for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Year of latest available data: 2013 (2011 $PPP)

P20 profile:
Agenda 2030 includes the specific commitment to Leave
No One Behind. Together with Sustainable Development
Goal 10 to reduce inequality, this requires faster than average
progress for the poorest. The test is whether the gap between
the poorest 20% of people (the P20) and everyone else
is reducing or getting wider.
The P20 Initiative uses data to show whether the poorest 20%
of people are getting their fair share of attention, investment
and opportunity. It uses three bellwether indicators of progress:
income, nutrition and civil registration and it promotes all data
being disaggregated by Income Quintile, Gender, Geography,
Age and Disability.
This profile provides key available data about the status
of the P20 in Kyrgyzstan.
691,090 people in Kyrgyzstan are among
the poorest 20% of the world’s population – the
global P20. That is 12% of the total population
and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Kyrgyzstan – live on between $2.09
and $2.91 a day compared with an average $5.72
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 1999 the gap between the national P20 and
everyone else in Kyrgyzstan was $3.49 and
in 2013 it was $3.38.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
Nutrition is fundamental to the ability to learn
and earn. Children who experience poor nutrition
can suffer lifelong disadvantage as a result.
In Kyrgyzstan, 13% of children under
five years old experience stunting. In the national P20 18%
experience stunting compared with 12%
of the rest of the population.

text.b: stunting in children in the P20 compared with rest of country

page.text: Source: Development Initiatives based on UNICEF-WHO joint child
malnutrition estimates
Civil Registration means people count and
have rights. Worldwide around 71% of children
are birth registered. If you are born into the
poorest 20% of people you are much less likely
to have your birth registered.
In Kyrgyzstan 96% of births in the
national P20 are registered compared to
98% in the rest of the population.

text.b: birth registration rates for children under five

page.text: Birth registration rates in Kyrgyzstan
have stayed constant.
Source: Development Initiatives based on World Bank World Development Indicators:
Completeness of birth registration %
Education is fundamental to a person’s
life chances.
As of 2009, 96% of people in Kyrgyzstan have
completed secondary school education.

text.b: percentage who have completed secondary education

page.text: 92% of people in the national P20 have completed
a secondary education compared with 97%
of the rest of the population.
Source: Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Poor health plays a major part in keeping people
in poverty. If you are among the P20 you are more
likely to suffer from preventable diseases and
to die earlier.
In Kyrgyzstan the under-five mortality rate
is 21 per 1,000 live births.
The under-five mortality rate among the P20
is 36 per 1,000 live births compared with 32
per 1,000 live births for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Year of latest available data: 2013 (2011 $PPP)
Based on latest available data which varies between countries – see original source
Based on latest available data which varies between countries – see original source

65,173,194 people in Indonesia are among

and they live on less than $2.54 a day.

for the rest of the population.

in 2013 it was $4.26.

P20 profile:
Agenda 2030 includes the specific commitment to Leave
No One Behind. Together with Sustainable Development
Goal 10 to reduce inequality, this requires faster than average
progress for the poorest. The test is whether the gap between
the poorest 20% of people (the P20) and everyone else
is reducing or getting wider.
The P20 Initiative uses data to show whether the poorest 20%
of people are getting their fair share of attention, investment
and opportunity. It uses three bellwether indicators of progress:
income, nutrition and civil registration and it promotes all data
being disaggregated by Income Quintile, Gender, Geography,
Age and Disability.
This profile provides key available data about the status
of the P20 in Viet Nam.
5,950,065 people in Viet Nam are among
the poorest 20% of the world’s population – the
global P20. That is 7% of the total population
and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Viet Nam – live on between $2.26
and $3.93 a day compared with an average $9.36
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 1999 the gap between the national P20 and
everyone else in Viet Nam was $2.28 and
in 2013 it was $6.52.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
Nutrition is fundamental to the ability to learn
and earn. Children who experience poor nutrition
can suffer lifelong disadvantage as a result.
In Viet Nam, 25% of children under
five years old experience stunting. It is not possible to
disaggregate stunting rates between the
national P20 and the rest of the population.

text.b: stunting in children in the P20 compared with rest of country

page.text: Source: Development Initiatives based on UNICEF-WHO joint child
malnutrition estimates
Civil Registration means people count and
have rights. Worldwide around 71% of children
are birth registered. If you are born into the
poorest 20% of people you are much less likely
to have your birth registered.
In Viet Nam 91% of births in the
national P20 are registered compared to
98% in the rest of the population.

text.b: birth registration rates for children under five

page.text: Birth registration rates in Viet Nam
have increased.
Source: Development Initiatives based on World Bank World Development Indicators:
Completeness of birth registration %
Education is fundamental to a person’s
life chances.
As of 2009, 65% of people in Viet Nam have
completed secondary school education.

text.b: percentage who have completed secondary education

page.text: 60% of people in the national P20 have completed
a secondary education compared with 90%
of the rest of the population.
Source: Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Poor health plays a major part in keeping people
in poverty. If you are among the P20 you are more
likely to suffer from preventable diseases and
to die earlier.
In Viet Nam the under-five mortality rate
is 22 per 1,000 live births.
The under-five mortality rate among the P20
is 53 per 1,000 live births compared with 25
per 1,000 live births for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Year of latest available data: 2013 (2011 $PPP)

and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Sri Lanka – live on between $2.38
and $3.60 a day compared with an average $9.13
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 1999 the gap between the national P20 and
everyone else in Sri Lanka was $4.25 and
in 2013 it was $6.33.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
Nutrition is fundamental to the ability to learn
and earn. Children who experience poor nutrition
can suffer lifelong disadvantage as a result.
In Sri Lanka, 17% of children under
five years old experience stunting. It is not possible to
disaggregate stunting rates between the
national P20 and the rest of the population.

text.b: stunting in children in the P20 compared with rest of country

page.text: Source: Development Initiatives based on UNICEF-WHO joint child
malnutrition estimates
Civil Registration means people count and
have rights. Worldwide around 71% of children
are birth registered. If you are born into the
poorest 20% of people you are much less likely
to have your birth registered.
In Sri Lanka 97% of births in the
national P20 are registered compared to
98% in the rest of the population.

text.b: birth registration rates for children under five

page.text: Source: Development Initiatives based on World Bank World Development Indicators:
Completeness of birth registration %
Education is fundamental to a person’s
life chances.
As of 2009, 74% of people in Sri Lanka have
completed secondary school education.

text.b: percentage who have completed secondary education

page.text: 77% of people in the national P20 have completed
a secondary education compared with 91%
of the rest of the population.
Source: Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Poor health plays a major part in keeping people
in poverty. If you are among the P20 you are more
likely to suffer from preventable diseases and
to die earlier.
In Sri Lanka the under-five mortality rate
is 9 per 1,000 live births.
Data is not available that allows us to disaggregate
under-five mortality based on income and
therefore we are unable to see this information
for the P20 versus the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)

P20 profile:
Agenda 2030 includes the specific commitment to Leave
No One Behind. Together with Sustainable Development
Goal 10 to reduce inequality, this requires faster than average
progress for the poorest. The test is whether the gap between
the poorest 20% of people (the P20) and everyone else
is reducing or getting wider.
The P20 Initiative uses data to show whether the poorest 20%
of people are getting their fair share of attention, investment
and opportunity. It uses three bellwether indicators of progress:
income, nutrition and civil registration and it promotes all data
being disaggregated by Income Quintile, Gender, Geography,
Age and Disability.
This profile provides key available data about the status
of the P20 in Palestine.
35,619 people in Palestine are among
the poorest 20% of the world’s population – the
global P20. That is 1% of the total population
and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Palestine – live on less than $5.50
a day compared with an average $12.62
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 1999 the gap between the national P20 and
everyone else in Palestine was $8.59 and
in 2013 it was $8.42.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
Nutrition is fundamental to the ability to learn
and earn. Children who experience poor nutrition
can suffer lifelong disadvantage as a result.
In Palestine, 7% of children under
five years old experience stunting. In the national P20 7%
experience stunting compared with 7%
of the rest of the population.

text.b: stunting in children in the P20 compared with rest of country

page.text: Source: Development Initiatives based on UNICEF-WHO joint child
malnutrition estimates
Civil Registration means people count and
have rights. Worldwide around 71% of children
are birth registered. If you are born into the
poorest 20% of people you are much less likely
to have your birth registered.
In Palestine 100% of births in the
national P20 are registered compared to
99% in the rest of the population.

text.b: birth registration rates for children under five

page.text: Birth registration rates in Palestine
have stayed constant.
Source: Development Initiatives based on World Bank World Development Indicators:
Completeness of birth registration %
Education is fundamental to a person’s
life chances.
As of 2015, 60% of people in Palestine have
completed secondary school education.

text.b: percentage who have completed secondary education

page.text: 77% of people in the national P20 have completed
a secondary education compared with 88%
of the rest of the population.
Source: Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Poor health plays a major part in keeping people
in poverty. If you are among the P20 you are more
likely to suffer from preventable diseases and
to die earlier.
In Palestine the under-five mortality rate
is 19 per 1,000 live births.
Data is not available that allows us to disaggregate
under-five mortality based on income and
therefore we are unable to see this information
for the P20 versus the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Year of latest available data: 2013 (2011 $PPP)
Based on latest available data which varies between countries – see original source
Based on latest available data which varies between countries – see original source

of the P20 in the Dominican Republic.

text.b: the P20 in the Dominican Republic

page.text: 599,989 people in the Dominican Republic are among
the poorest 20% of the world’s population – the
global P20. That is 6% of the total population
and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within the Dominican Republic – live on between $2.43
and $4.31 a day compared with an average $14.48
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 1999 the gap between the national P20 and
everyone else in the Dominican Republic was $14.30 and
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
Nutrition is fundamental to the ability to learn
and earn. Children who experience poor nutrition
can suffer lifelong disadvantage as a result.
In the Dominican Republic, 7% of children under
five years old experience stunting. In the national P20 12%
experience stunting compared with 6%
of the rest of the population.

text.b: stunting in children in the P20 compared with rest of country

page.text: Source: Development Initiatives based on UNICEF-WHO joint child
malnutrition estimates
Civil Registration means people count and
have rights. Worldwide around 71% of children
are birth registered. If you are born into the
poorest 20% of people you are much less likely
to have your birth registered.
In the Dominican Republic 73% of births in the
national P20 are registered compared to
94% in the rest of the population.

text.b: birth registration rates for children under five

page.text: Birth registration rates in the Dominican Republic
have increased.
Source: Development Initiatives based on World Bank World Development Indicators:
Completeness of birth registration %
Education is fundamental to a person’s
life chances.
As of 2015, 57% of people in the Dominican Republic have
completed secondary school education.

text.b: percentage who have completed secondary education

page.text: 78% of people in the national P20 have completed
a secondary education compared with 86%
of the rest of the population.
Source: Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Poor health plays a major part in keeping people
in poverty. If you are among the P20 you are more
likely to suffer from preventable diseases and
to die earlier.
In the Dominican Republic the under-five mortality rate
is 31 per 1,000 live births.
The under-five mortality rate among the P20
is 42 per 1,000 live births compared with 30
per 1,000 live births for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)

P20 profile:
Agenda 2030 includes the specific commitment to Leave
No One Behind. Together with Sustainable Development
Goal 10 to reduce inequality, this requires faster than average
progress for the poorest. The test is whether the gap between
the poorest 20% of people (the P20) and everyone else
is reducing or getting wider.
The P20 Initiative uses data to show whether the poorest 20%
of people are getting their fair share of attention, investment
and opportunity. It uses three bellwether indicators of progress:
income, nutrition and civil registration and it promotes all data
being disaggregated by Income Quintile, Gender, Geography,
Age and Disability.
This profile provides key available data about the status
of the P20 in Venezuela.
2,960,860 people in Venezuela are among
the poorest 20% of the world’s population – the
global P20. That is 10% of the total population
and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Venezuela – live on between $0.01
and $4.89 a day compared with an average $17.45
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 1999 the gap between the national P20 and
everyone else in Venezuela was $9.82 and
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
Nutrition is fundamental to the ability to learn
and earn. Children who experience poor nutrition
can suffer lifelong disadvantage as a result.

text.b: stunting in children in the P20 compared with rest of country

page.text: Source: Development Initiatives based on UNICEF-WHO joint child
malnutrition estimates
Civil Registration means people count and
have rights. Worldwide around 71% of children
are birth registered. If you are born into the
poorest 20% of people you are much less likely
to have your birth registered.

text.b: birth registration rates for children under five

page.text: Source: Development Initiatives based on World Bank World Development Indicators:
Completeness of birth registration %
Education is fundamental to a person’s
life chances.
As of 2015, 70% of people in Venezuela have
completed secondary school education.

text.b: percentage who have completed secondary education

page.text: 70% of people in the national P20 have completed
a secondary education compared with 82%
of the rest of the population.
Source: Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Poor health plays a major part in keeping people
in poverty. If you are among the P20 you are more
likely to suffer from preventable diseases and
to die earlier.
In Venezuela the under-five mortality rate
is 16 per 1,000 live births.
Data is not available that allows us to disaggregate
under-five mortality based on income and
therefore we are unable to see this information
for the P20 versus the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Year of latest available data: 2013 (2011 $PPP)
Based on latest available data which varies between countries – see original source
Based on latest available data which varies between countries – see original source

Civil Registration means people count and
have rights. Worldwide around 71% of children
are birth registered. If you are born into the
poorest 20% of people you are much less likely
to have your birth registered.
In Tonga 92% of births in the
national P20 are registered compared to
94% in the rest of the population.

life chances.

completed secondary school education.

page.text: Source: Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Poor health plays a major part in keeping people
in poverty. If you are among the P20 you are more
likely to suffer from preventable diseases and
to die earlier.
In Tonga the under-five mortality rate
is 16 per 1,000 live births.
Data is not available that allows us to disaggregate
under-five mortality based on income and
therefore we are unable to see this information
for the P20 versus the rest of the population.

P20 profile:
Agenda 2030 includes the specific commitment to Leave
No One Behind. Together with Sustainable Development
Goal 10 to reduce inequality, this requires faster than average
progress for the poorest. The test is whether the gap between
the poorest 20% of people (the P20) and everyone else
is reducing or getting wider.
The P20 Initiative uses data to show whether the poorest 20%
of people are getting their fair share of attention, investment
and opportunity. It uses three bellwether indicators of progress:
income, nutrition and civil registration and it promotes all data
being disaggregated by Income Quintile, Gender, Geography,
Age and Disability.
This profile provides key available data about the status
of the P20 in Tuvalu.
830 people in Tuvalu are among
the poorest 20% of the world’s population – the
global P20. That is 8% of the total population
and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Tuvalu – live on between $2.25
and $3.63 a day compared with an average $9.61
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 1999 the gap between the national P20 and
everyone else in Tuvalu was $6.68 and
in 2013 it was $6.90.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
Nutrition is fundamental to the ability to learn
and earn. Children who experience poor nutrition
can suffer lifelong disadvantage as a result.

text.b: stunting in children in the P20 compared with rest of country

to have your birth registered.

national P20 are registered compared to
53% in the rest of the population.

P20 profile:

text.b: The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia

page.text: Agenda 2030 includes the specific commitment to Leave
No One Behind. Together with Sustainable Development
Goal 10 to reduce inequality, this requires faster than average
progress for the poorest. The test is whether the gap between
the poorest 20% of people (the P20) and everyone else
is reducing or getting wider.
The P20 Initiative uses data to show whether the poorest 20%
of people are getting their fair share of attention, investment
and opportunity. It uses three bellwether indicators of progress:
income, nutrition and civil registration and it promotes all data
being disaggregated by Income Quintile, Gender, Geography,
Age and Disability.
This profile provides key available data about the status
of the P20 in Macedonia.
188,496 people in Macedonia are among
the poorest 20% of the world’s population – the
global P20. That is 9% of the total population
and they live on less than $2.54 a day.
The national P20 – the poorest 20% of people
within Macedonia – live on between $1.60
and $4.24 a day compared with an average $11.54
for the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
In 1999 the gap between the national P20 and
everyone else in Macedonia was $5.70 and
in 2013 it was $8.97.
Source: Development Initiatives based on PovcalNet
Nutrition is fundamental to the ability to learn
and earn. Children who experience poor nutrition
can suffer lifelong disadvantage as a result.
In Macedonia, 5% of children under
five years old experience stunting. In the national P20 7%
experience stunting compared with 4%
of the rest of the population.

text.b: stunting in children in the P20 compared with rest of country

page.text: Source: Development Initiatives based on UNICEF-WHO joint child
malnutrition estimates
Civil Registration means people count and
have rights. Worldwide around 71% of children
are birth registered. If you are born into the
poorest 20% of people you are much less likely
to have your birth registered.
In Macedonia 99% of births in the
national P20 are registered compared to
100% in the rest of the population.

text.b: birth registration rates for children under five

page.text: Source: Development Initiatives based on World Bank World Development Indicators:
Completeness of birth registration %
Education is fundamental to a person’s
life chances.
As of 2002, 48% of people in Macedonia have
completed secondary school education.

text.b: percentage who have completed secondary education

page.text: 60% of people in the national P20 have completed
a secondary education compared with 94%
of the rest of the population.
Source: Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Poor health plays a major part in keeping people
in poverty. If you are among the P20 you are more
likely to suffer from preventable diseases and
to die earlier.
In Macedonia the under-five mortality rate
is 12 per 1,000 live births.
Data is not available that allows us to disaggregate
under-five mortality based on income and
therefore we are unable to see this information
for the P20 versus the rest of the population.
Source: Development Initiatives based on Demographic Health Surveys (DHS)
Year of latest available data: 2013 (2011 $PPP)
